titleStmt.title: The divels legend. or: a learned cachephochysme containing the confession of the leaguers fayth : wherein doctour Pantaloun, and Zanie his pupill, doo teach that all hope ought to be grounded on the puissant King Phillip of Spaine, and vpon all the happie apostles of the holy league, and that they ought not to doo as the Brytans, English-men, and Protestants doo; which beleeue in God onely, harkening rather to the voyce of Iesus Christ, than vnto their holy Father the Pope. Composed in Rome by the reuerend Father Iuuenall Borget, and sent vnto the gentlemen of England by Charles Cyprian. Translated according to the French coppie.
titleStmt.author: Borget, Juvenall.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 20 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 11 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

Images scanned from microfilm: (Early English books, 1475-1640 ; 177:09, 644:08)

titleStmt.title: The divels legend. or: a learned cachephochysme containing the confession of the leaguers fayth : wherein doctour Pantaloun, and Zanie his pupill, doo teach that all hope ought to be grounded on the puissant King Phillip of Spaine, and vpon all the happie apostles of the holy league, and that they ought not to doo as the Brytans, English-men, and Protestants doo; which beleeue in God onely, harkening rather to the voyce of Iesus Christ, than vnto their holy Father the Pope. Composed in Rome by the reuerend Father Iuuenall Borget, and sent vnto the gentlemen of England by Charles Cyprian. Translated according to the French coppie.
titleStmt.author: Borget, Juvenall.

publicationStmt.publisher: [By J. Danter for] Thomas Gosson, and are to be sold at his shop by London Bridge gate,,

notesStmt.note: Caption title, leaf B2r, reads: A nevv pleasant and delightfull astrologie, inuented by reuerend Maister Harlequin the royall astrologer calculated for the leaguers merydian.
The first titlepage is on a separate folding leaf. B1 is blank and the second part, with "A nevv pleasant and delightfull astrologie" heading as above, begins on B2r--STC.
"A nevv pleasant and delightfull astrologie.." is identified as STC 11279a on reel 644.
Reproductions of the originals in the Bodleian Library and the Folger Shakespeare Library (part 2 only).
Appears at reel 177 (Bodleian Library) and at reel 644 (Folger Shakespeare Library, part 2 only).

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2006-07 Apex CoVantageKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2006-08 Judith SiefringText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: THE DIVELS LEGEND. OR: A Learned Cachephochy≈øme containing the Confe≈øsion of the Leaguers Fayth: Wherein Doctour Pantaloun, and Zanie his Pupill, doo teach that all hope ought to be grounded on the Pui≈ø≈øant King Phillip of Spaine, and vpon all the happie Apo≈øtles of the holy League, and that they ought not to doo as the Brytans, Engli≈øh-men, and Protestants doo; which beleeue in God onely, harkening rather to the voyce of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, than vnto their holy Father the Pope.
Compo≈øed in Rome by the reuerend Father Iuuenall Borget, and ≈øent vnto the Gentlemen of England by Charles Cyprian.

p.hi: Tran≈ølated according to the French Coppie.

div.p: Printed at London for Thomas Go≈ø≈øon, and are to be ≈øold at his shop by London Bridge gate. 1595.

div.head: The Diuels Legend. Or A learned Cakephochy≈øme, containing the confe≈ø≈øion of the Leaguers faith: handled betvveene Docter Pantaloun, and Zanie his pupell.

sp.speaker: Pantaloun.
sp.p:
ZAny finding in my ≈øelfe an immoderate care of thy poore ≈øoule, which like a fooli≈øh birde couets to flye into Hell ere her pinnions haue ≈øtrength to beare her from her necks breaking, and ≈øeeing thou de≈øi≈øte≈øt from ble≈ø≈øing thy forehead with thy right hands cro≈ø≈øing, as if the ≈øigne of the Crucifix were a bug-beare to ≈øcarre away thy ble≈ø≈øings, and that thou abiure≈øt the touche of holy water, forget≈øt thy praiers, and ha≈øt lo≈øt the memorable v≈øe of thy Beads, which like the check of a clock kept time to thy tongues bable:
I would faine know ≈øince all the memorable: ≈øeruice of thy auntient diuinitie is forgotten, in what new diuell now of late thou repo≈øe≈øt thy new beleeuings.

sp.speaker: Zanie.
sp.p: My good Mai≈øter, my Tutor, or the fountaine from whence I haue begotten mine in≈øtruction, be not ignorant, that earlie in the morning after I haue religiou≈ølie cald vpon the great Creator of good cheere, and with infinite Aues ≈øaluted the crim≈øon virgin of the darke celler, and with the helpe of their two dieties, filled the emptine≈ø≈øe of my ≈øeldome ≈øati≈øfied belly: I then repo≈øe all my faith, build the groundworke of my hope, and plant the mightie mountaine of my charitie in the holy (O lie) league, conioyned with her happie Apo≈øtle, ≈øcorning to imitate the king-counterfaiting Hugonites, which beleeue onely in God and none other.

sp.speaker: Pantaloun.
sp.p: I pray thee my good di≈øciple, tell me what bea≈øt is that which thou calle≈øt the holy league, and what creatures are tho≈øe which thou bapti≈øe≈øt her Apo≈øtels?

sp.speaker: Zanie.
sp.p:
What bea≈øt in the Deuils name? of my hone≈øty
Tutor I ≈ømile at the ≈øimplene≈ø≈øe of thy que≈øtion: why it is the bea≈øt of all bea≈øts: that which makes the be≈øt the mo≈øt bea≈øtlie≈øt, and the mo≈øt bea≈øtlie≈øt be≈øt in a bea≈øtly cen≈øure; it is the de≈øire of lu≈øt, idlene≈ø≈øe inuention, and the be≈øt bloome in ambitious ≈øpring: to wit, ≈øhe is a faire whore violated by adulterous princes, confe≈øt & ab≈øolued by fal≈øe Prie≈øts, and vncontionably bribde by ignorant people; as for her Apo≈øtles, they are as Pope Sextus a better ≈øpaniard than a Go≈øpeller, truer to the one, than religious to the other, though hone≈øt to neither: the father and the Sonne, without the Holy gho≈øt, (for he like the vocatiue ca≈øe, is wanting in all their ≈øub≈øtantiues) which is to be vnder≈øtood the father of Spaine, the ≈øonne of Sauoy, and in≈øteed of the Holy-gho≈øt, the grand diuell of Loraine.

sp.speaker: Pantaloun.
sp.p: Recite to me then my good ≈øcholler, all the articles of thy Creede, grounded and made by tho≈øe Apo≈øtles, to the end that we may not onely heleeue, but the world may be wi≈øe in a≈ø≈øured knowledge, that thou art become a great Doctor in the Spani≈øh Macharon, or the diuels golden Legend.

sp.speaker: Zanie.
sp.p:
Tutor I will: Fir≈øt I beleeue in the mo≈øt great, mightie, and ≈øaint murthering king of Spaine: the creator of the new land, as much of the arche dominator or ≈øuperintendant of the poore Hugonites,
a≈ømuch of the Turkes great mai≈øter of France: as much as of England, Emperour or monarche: not fully ≈øo much of the world, as of the filthe and vncleanne≈ø≈øe in the world: I beleeue in his ≈øonne and in his daughter, his children and their children: I beleeue in that great, faire, well cut, and better combed beard the Duke of Tienops and of Sauoy, who by his rare and vn≈øearcheable vertue, is a≈øcended vp into the ≈øigne Gemini, together with the infant, pa≈ø≈øing many times by the wanton horned ≈øigne Capricornus: I beleeue in the great Me≈ø≈øias or Saluator the Duke of Parma, that he is dead, buried, and de≈øcended into hell: I beleeue in the great, gro≈ø≈øe, gray, and goodly head of the Duke De Mains which ≈øtands in more need of philo≈øophy, than beggars of almes: and to be briefe, for tediou≈øne≈ø≈øe is labor≈øome, I beleeue in the holy church of Lorraine, a≈ømuch Apo≈øtolike as Chri≈øtian, and to neither of both any thing at all allyed.

sp.speaker: Pantaloun.
sp.p: Into how many articles is this Creede or ≈øymbole deuided, and which be they.

sp.speaker: Zanie.
sp.p:
Into twelue, and the≈øe they are: Ambition, Enuy. Hypocri≈øie, Tyrannie, Slaunder, Flatterie, Trea≈øon, Sedition, Ignorance, Malice, Ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe, and Rebellion, and the≈øe my deare mai≈øter are the degrees or ladders ≈øteps, whereby all true catholiques mu≈øt be
receiued into the church of the league or Spani≈øh Synagogue.

sp.speaker: Pantaloun.
sp.p: But what is the intentiue meaning of the≈øe holy happy Apo≈øtles of the league, and what is the end of their ≈øo much admired excellencies.

sp.speaker: Zanie.
sp.p: The intention is mo≈øt good, becau≈øe in the ≈øeeming procreation of their acts they immitate God him≈øelfe, foreuen as he created all things for his owne glorie, ≈øo bring they forth all their factions, for their owne triumphes, only this difference, his is admired and reuerenced of all ≈øoules, theirs wondered at and hated of all what euer hath feeling of chri≈øtianitie.

sp.speaker: Pantaloun.
sp.p: But how gallop they or po≈øt they forwarde in this ≈øo meritorious or ble≈ø≈øed worke, or how ≈øweat they in the ferueneie of this holy action.

sp.speaker: Zanie.
sp.p:
Euen ≈øo and in ≈øuch manner as the three Sages which Pilgrim-like trauaild from the Orient, faining to wor≈øhip Chri≈øt, and plant him in too long for≈øaken France, bringing with them three pre≈øents,
Warre, Pe≈øtilence, and Famine, whil≈øt the Loade-≈øtarre to their trauaile, is hypocri≈øie and pre≈øumption.

sp.speaker: Pantaloun.
sp.p: But what fruite or profit ≈øhall redownd to this endle≈ø≈øe webbe of their continuall working?

sp.speaker: Zanie.
sp.p: If they ≈øowe Iuorie, they ≈øhall reape thornes, if they beget a mon≈øter, they ≈øhall bring forth a Chymera, if by their factious troubles they confound ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe in the beginning, by the re≈øidence of their euill, they ≈øhall finde bitterne≈ø≈øe in the ending.

sp.speaker: Pantaloun.
sp.p: How ≈øhall then my gallant pupill this thy holy league finde an end from the eternitie of her labor?

sp.speaker: Zanie.
sp.p: O my good mai≈øter, ≈øhe mu≈øt fir≈øt charitablie vi≈øite her deare holy father Lucifer, and her mother Pro≈øerpina, and all her worme eaten progenitors of Lorraine, for ≈øooner ≈øhall ≈øhe purcha≈øe a fee ≈øimple in any of their regions, than haue an e≈øtate for terme of life in the con≈øines of vnhappie France.

div.head: A nevv plea≈øant and delightfull A≈øtrologie, inuented by reuerend Mai≈øter Harlequin the royall A≈øtrologer, calculated for the Leaguers Merydian.
The fir≈øt error is in the twelue ≈øignes.
div.p:
THE Leaguers haue brought into Fraunce ≈øo manye rauenous Woolues, that the poore ≈øigne of Mutton is for euer bani≈øht their Zodiack, they haue in≈øtald ≈øo many Cod-peeces in their Cathedrals, that the pure ≈øigne of the Virgine is as rare to be ≈øeene, as thunder in winter, or a million of black Swans in a fi≈øhpond, and they haue made ≈øuch a tole-free open pa≈ø≈øage, vnto whole armies of di≈øordered
per≈øons that are boundle≈ø≈øe in their villanie, that the ≈øigne of Lybra, or the equall poy≈øing ballance is ca≈ø≈øierd as vnprofitable among≈øt them, but it is mo≈øt true, and too true, that they haue eleuated in their Horrizon, and in≈øtald in triumphant credit, the great Taurus or bulbegger of Lorraine, with a multitude of Caprycornians and Sagitarians, which bend all their hornes and hooues again≈øt Burbon, but I may prophe≈øie vnto them that they haue not found Saint Seba≈øtian which patiently indured the Darts which were ≈øhot into him.

div.head: The ≈øecond error is in the Planets.
div.p: AGaine, the≈øe Leagwers ≈øhowe them≈øelues more Dogs than Doctors, that in ≈øtead of following the other Planets which acknowledge the Sunne as their common Prince, or principall ≈øub≈øtance of their borrowed ≈øplendor, yet will they that Mercury of Britaine, and Venus his wife, and all ≈øuch wandring ≈øtarres like them≈øelues, ≈øhall bend their borrowed bonfiers again≈øt the true ≈øonne of Fraunce, which notwith≈øtanding of his owne beneuolence‚ñ™ hath giuen them the little glimmering brightne≈ø≈øe which they haue, and which is wor≈øe than the wor≈øte of all, after that they hauing lo≈øt the true naturall heate of that glorious ≈øunne, they ≈øearche the coldene≈ø≈øe of the Satournian Spaniard, both fro≈øtie in goodne≈ø≈øe, dried by with couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and as melanchollyas ambition can make him.

div.head: The third error is in the Climates.
div.p: NOw the≈øe Rabins or ≈øeemeing (though altogether vn≈øound) Doctors, pretending deepe in≈øight into Mil≈øtone A≈øtrologie, ≈øeeking to ≈øet fire vpon the hou≈øe of Burbon, and ≈øtuffe her walles with ≈øtrange vermin or mon≈øtrous creatures, haue whi≈øpered in the Spaniards eares like the downe-falling of a water to a thundring Myll, and with that ≈øecret prattle haue made him beleeue that Fraunce is colder than Spaine, and more temperate for the diuels dwelling: in ≈øuch ≈øort that the Spani≈øh Marrans couetous of the pure≈øt ayre, bring their intemperance into our clymate, but they are mightily deceiued in the fooli≈øhne≈ø≈øe of their opinions, for that often times and mo≈øt commonly, tho≈øe which ≈øoiourne and dwell in their countrie of Spaine, notwith≈øtanding it is much whotter, yet doe they liue longer than they which come into Fraunce, Flaunders, or England.

div.head: The fourth error is in the di≈øtinction of times.
div.p: THe≈øe mon≈øtrous lyers, the Serpents Schollers, make al≈øo the poore deceiued people of the League beleeue, that the times or ≈øea≈øons are much differing one from the other, and that in ≈øome they mu≈øt v≈øe purgations, in others co≈øticke medicines, and in ≈øome neither of both; as in the canicular, or dogge dayes: but if you will beleeue me (gentle readers) the fooles of Parris ≈øtand in no neede of purgations, neither yet of the new dyet, either by emptine≈ø≈øe to ea≈øe their bellyes, or by ≈øparene≈ø≈øe of repa≈øt, to keepe their ≈øheetes cleanly: the Spaniards al≈øo for the mo≈øt part, and principally tho≈øe which come into Fraunce, feare hell ten times more than the Dogge dayes. When they ≈øay that ≈øuch a ≈øea≈øon ≈øhall be windie, ≈øuch a time raine, and ≈øuch a day faire plea≈øant weather, all that ≈øerueth to nothing, or to no purpo≈øe, for the foole antidated before in mine A≈øtrologie, which behoulding the conuer≈øion, feare neither winde, raine, nor faire weather, (God be thanked) for if they chaunce to be dabled a little with walking vp and downe the towne, the day ≈øhall come I hope, when they ≈øhall be duckt ouerhead and eares, or els vtterly drowned.

div.head: The fifth error is in the Ecclyp≈øes.
div.p: THe≈øe logger-head learned Leaguers, make certaine di≈øtinctions of the Moone ecclip≈øed and not ecclip≈øed; but I that am not ignorant but know very well, that the Moone hath no power to gaze vpon the Sunnes forehead, nor to giue aime to his brightne≈ø≈øe, holde this for a certaine actiome, that ≈øhe ≈øhall alwaies be ecclyp≈øed, and that euery one of them cannot be but ecclip≈øed in true duties or indeuours, and walke in the darke like boyes at hood-man blinde; which is the cau≈øe that diuers of them doe fall, and if they ≈øcape breaking their necks, yet they loo≈øe them≈øelues, altogether hopele≈ø≈øe for euer recouering one minute of day light, or any iotte of ≈øuccour at their great Me≈ø≈øias the Duke of Parma.

div.head: The ≈øixth error, is in the marks, or notes.
div.p: THey propo≈øe and carrie before them the golden number, but yet in de≈øpight of all the promi≈øes of the huge King of Ca≈øtile, I am a≈ø≈øured that in the end the poore Pary≈øyans will finde it, but a beggars reckoning; it is very true, that the women ≈øhall haue two dominicall letters, ≈øo much the greater, by how much the greater they are inamoured with the greate≈øt Alphabet, to wit, great O. and great Q. And when you would know the yeare of the holy Barracados of Parris, or rather if you will the day when the Guy≈øards fighteth only with their balafte, you ≈øhall need but to make your hone≈øt repaire to me your a≈ø≈øured friend Harlequin who knowes not onely the moouing of the elements, but the ≈øecret working of euery ≈øtarre in the heauens.

div.head: The ≈øeauenth error is in the di≈øpo≈øition and cour≈øe of the yeare.
div.p: THe≈øe Leaguers make the yeares to be twelue moneths, but the Parry≈øyans which haue watcht ≈øo many nights, and ≈øtood ≈øo many howers Sentinels on the walks, ≈øhall not be paide for ≈øixe moneths; they make ≈øixe daies in the week, alwaies bani≈øhing Sunday as an idle note in the Callender: but for Friday and Saturday, they are alwaies more villanou≈ølie ≈øharpe≈øet, and know farre wor≈ø≈øe tyrants in the Spani≈øh armie than in the Kings regiment; they make the day foure and twentie howers in length, but the poore hungrie Parri≈øians that haue neither dinde, ≈øupt nor can get a breakefa≈øt, ≈øweare the clockes lye, for it cannot be le≈ø≈øe then eight and fortie.

div.head: The eighth error, is in the prediction of all that ≈øhall happen vnto the Leaguers from their conception, vntill their de≈øcending into Hell.
div.p: THe godly and ble≈ø≈øed Merdologians, or rather Fortune-tellers, make the A≈ø≈øe head abu≈øed Leaguers beleeue, that they are borne vnder the ≈øigne of the Lion, and ≈øo con≈øequently through that influence, they ≈øhall all prooue renowned warriours; but I di≈øcent from their iudgements, for I beleeue that they ≈øhall all rather be borne vnder the Crabbe, or demi Creui≈ø≈øe; learning to goe more backwarde than euer they wente forward, and for their education, they ≈øhall vndoubtedly be brought vpp vnder the ≈øigne of Aquarius, becau≈øe at their birthes Wine was bani≈øht for inflaming the liuer: and I holde it certaine in rules of their Natiuitie, that there ≈øhall be many Gramarians and Mu≈øitians among≈øt them, who ≈øhall decline ≈øo much, and dimini≈øh ≈øo mightily, that beggerie and ≈øcorne ≈øhall be all their companions, and in the end they ≈øhall dye vnder the Spani≈øh Scorpion, if ≈øodainly before their times they be not annointed with the iuyce of Hemp≈øeede, to mend their falling euils.

div.head: The ninth error, is in the humor that ≈øhall rule among≈øt them.
div.p: NOw to giue them audatious bouldne≈ø≈øe, and to incourage them in their fooli≈øh and damned ra≈øh aduentures, the≈øe A≈øtrologians do promi≈øe them, that the humor of Iupiter ≈øhall haue influence and rule in their natiuities, but I, euen I noble Harlequin, by the afore≈øaid predictions, ≈øpeculations and coniectures, do conclude, that the melancholie humor ≈øhall be predominant and mai≈øter ouer them, which ≈øhall make them ≈øo phanta≈øticall and madde in their braines drunkenne≈ø≈øe, that diuers of them ≈øhall dreame in the night, that they are already mounted vpon the deuils wings, into the third heauen, and when they awake, they ≈øhall finde them≈øelues accompanied with ≈øhame and di≈øcredite, the very mon≈øters of the world, hauing no ≈øore but the earths barrenne≈ø≈øe: others ≈øhall dreame of certaine pri≈øes of Come and Wine, and forfeit the deare pri≈øes of their ≈øoule, ≈øelling their bodies to hell & eternall damnation‚ñ™ others, (and of them ≈øhall be an infinite number) ≈øhall dreame that they are Kings, and princely Gouernours of Realmes and Principallities, but when they awake, they ≈øhall finde them≈øelues the thridbare gouernours, fathers, and nouri≈øhers of fleas, Lice, and all manner of fle≈øhly per≈øecuters.

div.head: The tenth error is in the length of the Leaguers world.
div.p: DIui≈øion is the mother of de≈øtruction: and vnion the fir≈øt bringer forth of con≈øeruation or pro≈øperitie: whence it ≈øprings that the A≈øtrologians belonging to the League, conclude in their vnion a perpetuitie, but I arguing both in forme and figure, prooue the flat contrarie, for ≈øay I, they ≈øhall be ≈øo vnited in will, that looke what the one would haue, the other would be glad to cut his throate ≈øo he might attaine it: and during the time of their di≈øputation, who ≈øhall fir≈øt ≈øit downe and take the chiefe place at the table: I noble Harlequin a pa≈ø≈øing good Burbonian, will like an Vniuer≈øitie lurcher, licke all the fatte from their trenchers.
LONDON, Printed for Thomas Go≈ø≈øon, and are to be ≈øold at his ≈øhop by London bridge gate. 1595.
